Award.AwardTitle: Workshop/Collaborative Research: Interdisciplinary Methods for Disaster Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
While there have been many advances in disciplinary-specific quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods approaches for disaster research, interdisciplinary methods in the field have not yet been sufficiently inventoried or studied. In light of this gap in knowledge, the central objective of the workshop series is to bring together leading interdisciplinary researchers to advance the science and practice of interdisciplinary research for hazards and disasters. The expected products of the workshop series are two clearly defined deliverables: a special journal issue dedicated to understanding issues involved in framing and organizing interdisciplinary research, and an edited book volume focused on developing methodological guidance for interdisciplinary teams. The workshops will engage a broad range of disciplinary perspectives from a wide array of participants. The journal issue and edited volume will be designed to reach researchers engaged in or interested in interdisciplinary disaster research, helping to advance the field, to educate current and future generations, and to encourage ongoing discussions of methodological perspectives on disaster research.

This work will (1) inventory interdisciplinary methodological approaches and associated epistemological and theoretical underpinnings used across the disaster life-cycle; (2) assess the theoretical and methodological approaches used to form and sustain interdisciplinary teams; (3) identify the major challenges that the field faces in terms of interdisciplinary methods; (4) assess the unique contributions and methodological advances of interdisciplinary teams; (5) reveal the dynamics of implementing an interdisciplinary methodological approach; and (6) discuss interdisciplinary research, teaching, and next generation mentoring needs moving forward into the future. As such, the two workshops and associated deliverables will directly help to address gaps in knowledge regarding how, when, where, and to what ends interdisciplinary research is implemented. The activities will engage a team of leading interdisciplinary hazards and disaster researchers, resulting in new insights into the challenges and methods of interdisciplinary disaster research while also providing timely guidance for teams engaged in this type of scholarly activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported a workshop series on interdisciplinary methods and approaches for hazards and disaster research. These workshops, which were held in March 2017 and February 2018, brought together more than 40 experts from engineering, the social and physical sciences, the humanities, and public policy. The first workshop led to the development of 25 perspectives articles for a special issue of the journal Risk Analysis. The second workshop culminated in a proposal for an edited volume that is now under contract with Springer Nature. The book will be published as part of the global Disaster and Risk Research series. The scholarly publications and practical guidance that emerged from these initial workshops will help advance next-generation interdisciplinary scholarship in the hazards and disaster field.

This workshop series was initiated to help fill two main knowledge gaps. First, because disasters occur at the interface of natural, built, social, and economic environments, it is crucial that scientists work across disciplinary boundaries to accurately characterize the causes and consequences of those events. This often requires the use of novel research methods and approaches, which have not been systematically catalogued. Second, hazards and disaster researchers are increasingly encouraged by funding agencies and their institutions to work in multidisciplinary or interdisciplinary teams. Yet there is little available scholarship in the hazards and disaster field to help researchers understand the most effective processes for such team-based collaborations.

With these gaps in mind, the workshop series was designed to inventory existing interdisciplinary methods for hazards and disaster research; identify best-practice approaches for creating and sustaining interdisciplinary research teams; discuss ethical, analytical, logistical, and methodological challenges and opportunities at the frontiers of interdisciplinary research; and offer practical guidance for teaching and training next generation interdisciplinary researchers. The burgeoning Science of Team Science literature informed the workshop sessions and the publications that have followed.

The workshop series has led to major advancements in specifying integrative theories for informing interdisciplinary scholarship. In addition, publications from this series introduce and explain the analytical possibilities associated with various interdisciplinary methodologies, including agent-based modeling, simulations, interdependency analysis, uncertainty estimation, citizen science, story-telling, and visualization techniques. These methodological contributions are coupled with natural hazards-focused case study applications for floods, hurricanes, earthquakes, and a range of other extreme events. Moreover, this work contributes more broadly to scholarship on risk, emergency response, recovery, and resilience.

Much of the content generated from these workshops underscores how researchers can work more effectively across disciplinary boundaries to achieve integration in interdisciplinary teams. For example, researchers who participated in this series have introduced new approaches for developing common vocabularies through a novel “sharing meanings” approach and new team-building processes drawing on metacognition, or the practice of thinking about our thinking. Scholarship from this series also introduces ideas for evaluating the readiness and effectiveness of interdisciplinary teams. Several of the projects focus on how we can move the scientific breakthroughs generated from interdisciplinary research into the emergency management practice and policy spheres.

Members of historically underrepresented groups and an equal number of women and men participated in this workshop series. In addition, the workshops involved researchers at varying professional stages, ranging from early career to senior scholars. Three graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers contributed to the workshop development and were mentored by the two principal investigators.

Overall, these workshops helped advance interdisciplinary theory, methods, and approaches to hazards and disaster research, while also broadening and expanding the potential impact of this work.
